metadata.case_name: Assessee Firm v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: Assessee is a firm carrying on business at Surat with a branch at Bangkok to which it exported cloth from India; branch also made local purchases and sales.
During the last world war, business at Bangkok was in abeyance but restarted after termination of hostilities.

For assessment year 1949-50 (accounting year calendar 1949), assessee did not include Bangkok branch profits in return, stated books not available, requested estimate basis subject to s.34 or 35; assessed at 5% profit on exports to Bangkok in Surat books.
For assessment year 1950-51 (accounting year 1950? wait, calendar 1949? text implies similar), no reference to Bangkok branch in return, similar estimate made.
For assessment year 1951-52 (accounting year calendar 1950), Bangkok business profits not shown in return.
On January 11, 1952, Income-tax Officer issued notice under s.22(4) to produce profit and loss account, balance-sheet, relevant books.

On January 29, 1952, assessee replied that books at Bangkok, profit/loss and balance-sheet could not be drawn up unless partner Hatimbhai A. Malbary went there personally, no certainty when, promised production next year.
On January 31, 1952, ITO made estimate: sales Rs.7,50,000, net profits 5% i.e. Rs.37,500; assessment made.
On January 31, 1952, same day, ITO issued notice under s.28(3) requiring show cause why penalty under s.28(1)(c) for concealment of 1950 income not levied.
Assessee heard on notice; on January 22, 1954, ITO imposed penalty of Rs.20,000 as explanation not acceptable.

For assessment year 1952-53, assessee adopted similar attitude; after adjournments, on August 17, 1953, produced accounts and books of Bangkok branch showing profit of Rs.1,25,520 for calendar year 1950.
ITO commenced proceedings under s.34 for 1951-52, notice to submit return; assessee submitted return correctly stating profits for 1950.
On April 8, 1954, ITO issued further notice under s.28(3) show cause why penalty for deliberately concealing 1950 income; on February 28, 1957, imposed penalty of Rs.68,501.
Assessee appealed both penalty orders to Appellate Assistant Commissioner; appeals rejected.

Income-tax Appellate Tribunal: Cancelled first penalty Rs.20,000 (no basis as estimate stage); confirmed Rs.68,501 as guilt proved with definite knowledge of Rs.1,25,520 profit; not excessive. Revenue did not question cancellation of first.
Reference to Bombay High Court: Question - Whether levy of Rs.68,501 penalty for concealment in original return for 1951-52 legal? HC answered affirmative on April 13, 1960.
In s.34 return, assessee furnished correct particulars and produced books; no default therein. Notice for original concealment.
Tribunal finding: Assessee knew profits Rs.1,25,520, did not disclose originally, did not produce books, permitted estimate of Rs.37,500.

legal_issues.text: Whether the levy of Rs. 68,501/- as penalty for concealment in the original return for the assessment year 1951-52 is legal?
Whether second penalty order legal despite earlier penalty order for same concealment, and whether ITO had jurisdiction to impose higher penalty after ascertaining true facts.

petitioner_arguments.text: Second order for penalty illegal because one concealment, earlier penalty of Rs.20,000 imposed; no jurisdiction for second while first stood; second nullity ab initio; subsequent cancellation of first does not validate second.
When first penalty passed on Jan 22, 1954, ITO had full facts (books produced Aug 17, 1953), no right to later change to higher penalty.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: C. V. Govinderajulu Iyer v. Commissioner of Income tax, Madras

respondent_arguments.text: Penalties not on same facts: original assessment/penalty on estimate basis; second after knowledge of full facts of concealed income.

court_reasoning.text: Not question of jurisdiction; two penalties for same concealment cannot stand, but ITO entitled to recall earlier (estimate-based) and impose higher on true facts; omission to recall does not invalidate second; here first cancelled, only one order left, legal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Penalty under s.28 related to tax evaded if concealment succeeded.

court_reasoning.text: Govinderajulu observation (qualification on power if default known at final prior order) not subscribed to; anyway inapplicable: first penalty notice Jan 31, 1952 before books (Aug 1953); final prior assessment Jan 31, 1952 without knowledge of full concealment; assessee not heard on later concealment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Subsequently acquired knowledge irrelevant for first notice-based penalty.

holdings.text: Levy of Rs.68,501 penalty legal; ITO had jurisdiction to impose second/higher penalty after true facts known, even if earlier penalty not formally recalled.

precedents_cited.case_name: C. V. Govinderajulu Iyer v. Commissioner of Income tax, Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Cited by appellant for proposition no power to impose later penalty if facts known at prior final order; court distinguished and did not subscribe to qualification.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for notices, assessments, estimates, concealment penalties; penalty for concealment of income particulars.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding the Bombay High Court's affirmative answer to the reference question; confirmed legality of Rs.68,501 penalty imposed pursuant to second s.28(3) notice after true profits known, first penalty already cancelled by Tribunal.

key_quotes.text: It is indeed difficult to understand the action of the Department in splitting up one offence into two proceedings.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Tribunal observation on two penalties, but upheld second.

key_quotes.text: The penalty under the section has to be co-related to the amount of the tax which would have been evaded if the assessee had got away with the concealment.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning for allowing higher penalty on true facts.

key_quotes.text: We do not think that Rajamannar C.J. wished to state this qualification on the power of the Income-tax Officer as a proposition of law. It was not certainly necessary for the purposes of the case before him. We do not wish to be understood as subscribing to it as at present advised.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Court's refusal to follow obiter from precedent.
